text:
I’ll be joining @MSignorile on @SiriusXMProg at 5:30 EST to talk about what’s happening on Capitol Hill, the looming debt-ceiling battle, and some of the questions (and frustrations) I heard from constituents during last night’s Telephone Town Hall. 

Tune in if you can!

The President's political purges at the FBI and DOJ should alarm everyone.

He might claim this is about making these departments more efficient. But we all know what it’s really about: revenge and retribution.

Two lawsuits have already been filed challenging the President's extreme actions.

https://t.co/0bAkZHxepW

I know the past few weeks have been exhausting, and there is a long road ahead. We’ll use the tools we have in Congress. We’ll stand up + push back. We’ll use our voices. 

And if the American people use theirs, too, we will be able to hold the Administration accountable. (14/14)

Because the more informed people are about this Administration’s unhinged actions, the more engaged—and enraged—they become. And it’s that engagement and outrage that makes *our* words and actions so much more powerful.

Your voices really do matter. Keep using them! (13/14)

Still, even a post or thread can help you better understand the details + stakes of bills I vote on (or the President’s actions).

But social media can’t be our only platform. Videos. Town halls. Media appearances. All are important.

Simply put: We need to be everywhere. (12/14)

I will always explain what I vote on and why. That's my job. But legislation in the Trump era is going to be different. There are a lot of “gotcha” bills—ones that have a sensible-sounding title but absolutely awful text (the Laken Riley Act is a great example of this). (11/14)

But perhaps our most powerful tool is the ability to communicate with you—our constituents. To spell out, in plain terms, what’s really going on, and why it matters.

I take that responsibility seriously. And I know my colleagues do, too. (10/14)

On impeachment: Articles can be introduced by either party, but the majority decides whether they move forward. 

While this is an appealing option (we’ve done it before—when we controlled the House), with Republicans in control, the chances of making it stick are nil. (9/14)

But there are things we *can’t* do on our own:

❌ Confirm or deny nominees.
❌ Stop POTUS from issuing crazy orders.
❌ Control which bills get voted on in the House.
❌ Impeach (more below).

Until we’re back in the majority, there’s only so much we can control. (8/14)

None of this is easy. We are in uncharted waters. But we *will* keep fighting the President’s actions as best we can—and we will use every tool at our disposal to keep this Administration in check.

We understand the stakes. And we’re not going to back down. (7/14)

As for future court challenges: There are several ways to do this, like working w/ state AGs to challenge specific orders.

Last week, Maine’s AG joined colleagues in other states to sue the Administration, resulting in a temporary restraining order on the funding freeze.  (6/14)

The courts will play a critical role, too. The President is pushing the boundaries of the separation of powers. The only remedy is to challenge him by getting the courts to rule he's gone too far.   

We’ve already seen the courts block some of the Administration’s orders. (5/14)

On investigations: 

The minority in Congress can’t control hearings or subpoenas. But we can call and question witnesses; work with whistleblowers to uncover vital information; and take our findings to the public.

All these tools are on the table. And we’ll use them. (4/14)

The Constitution is clear on Congress’s power of the purse. The Administration’s directive to “impound” funds from Congress is unconstitutional. While they rescinded a memo calling for a total freeze, they’re still stealing these funds.

We *will* fight them in the courts. (3/14)

Without getting too deep in the constitutional weeds, Congress has several powers at its disposal, including:
  
🟢 The power to spend.
🟢 The power to investigate.
🟢 The power to challenge actions in court.
🟢 The power to impeach.

Let’s take them one at a time. (2/14)

Amid the flurry of extreme actions taken by the Administration, there’s one question I keep hearing:

“What are you going to *do* about it?”

It’s a fair point—especially when the President has thus far avoided any real accountability.

I’ll do my best to address it. (1/14)

We need to call this illegal and unconstitutional act what it is: a hostile takeover of our government by an unelected billionaire.

The American people deserve answers to how and why this was allowed to happen. There must be an immediate Congressional investigation.

The idea that Elon musk and his cronies now have control over these levers of government is absolute insanity. The damage they could inflict—on our economy, and on the lives and livelihoods of millions of citizens—is beyond comprehension.

For those who don’t know, these systems handle trillions of dollars in payments submitted by agencies across the government—including Social Security checks and tax refunds. They also contain highly sensitive information about American taxpayers.

Did anyone elect Elon Musk?

Has Congress confirmed him for an actual position?

No? 

Then why was he given sweeping, unfettered access to the U.S. Treasury payment systems?
https://t.co/nAtdVOxfxi

In the days and weeks ahead, we must seek answers and understand exactly what happened—so we can ensure that a devastating accident like this never happens again

https://t.co/aXUpIiptkU

This is an unimaginable tragedy. My heart breaks for the passengers, crew, and service members who lost their lives, and for all their loved ones. I'm grateful to the first responders who worked tirelessly throughout the night and are continuing with recovery efforts today.

The President is required to give Congress 30 days notice—and a good reason—before removing an IG.

In the dead of night, he unlawfully fired at least 15 without cause.

His goal is clear: to replace these independent watchdogs with partisan hacks.

https://t.co/c7jltP1pBr

Congrats to Maine's semifinalists for @beardfoundation awards! 🏆🎉👏

From amazing chefs + bakers to outstanding restaurants + bars, you represent the very best of Maine’s iconic food scene. We’re so proud to see your hard work and creativity recognized on the national stage! https://t.co/yxYBikyFLP

Like pulling us out of the WHO, this is just bad leadership. And a slap in the face to future generations.

130+ of my @HouseDemocrats colleagues and I strongly urge the President to reverse this dangerous withdrawal. The stakes are too high. (2/2)

https://t.co/qJxZSv5IN1

The President's decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement isn’t just petty and shortsighted. It goes against the greatest scientific consensus of our times—while hindering our ability to negotiate with other countries on what is, at its core, an international crisis. (1/2)

As ranking member of @AppropsDems Interior and Environment Subcommittee, which oversees funding for @smithsonian, I’m proud to support initiatives like the Giant Panda Conservation Program.

If you’re in D.C., don’t miss the chance to meet Bao Li and Qing Bao in person!

Timeline cleanser! 🐼

Bao Li + Qing Bao made their official public debut @NationalZoo today! These adorable ambassadors are carrying on a legacy that began in 1972, when the first giant pandas arrived at the Zoo, symbolizing cross-cultural collaboration between the U.S. + China. https://t.co/q6Y9TJECdb

The Forest Service and other public lands agencies already struggle with adequate funding. This bill significantly expands its mission to fight wildfires without providing the resources to do so.

Ultimately, that makes the "Fix Our Forests Act" one big empty promise. (6/6)

Finally, the bill isn’t even funded! Should we establish a community wildfire defense research program to look at how we can build more wildfire resistant restructures, including using mass timber? Yes. Does this bill provide resources for an actual research program? No. (5/6)

The California fires were caused by brush igniting and were exacerbated by extreme winds. Forest management plays an important role in addressing wildfires, but this bill doesn’t provide resources for community-resilience and rebuilding that are needed in the region. (4/6)

I recognize and support the important role forest-harvesting and management plays in Maine and across the country. But the bill goes too far in some areas of environmental review—and undermines protections for biodiversity. (3/6)

Maine is the most forested U.S. state, so these are issues I take seriously. However, 94% of Maine forests are privately owned—not federal land.

Achieving responsible, balanced forest management requires *real* investment and community involvement.

This bill falls short. (2/6)

🧵The devastating wildfires in California are a harrowing reminder of the dangers of climate change—and the importance of wildfire response.

While I support parts of the “Fix Our Forests Act,” the benefits do not outweigh the concerns I have.

Here’s why I voted NO: (1/6)

Infanticide is already illegal in all 50 states. In 2002, Congress passed a bill *unanimously* to codify that fact. 

This bill fabricates a problem that does not exist.

This is yet another attempt to limit access to reproductive health care—and criminalize those who provide it.

So, are they really worried about straining the electric grid, or do they just want to line the pockets of Big Tech and Big Oil? (2/2)

https://t.co/SYzEJ9wTFm

On Tuesday, the President revoked Biden-era vehicle pollution and fuel economy standards.

Why? He thinks too many EVs will strain the electric grid. 

Meanwhile, he wants to invest half-a-*trillion* dollars in AI, which will require far more energy than meeting EV goals. (1/2)

To call January 6th a "peaceful protest" or a “day of love” is simply delusional. 

We cannot let President Trump and the Republican Party rewrite history. (2/2)

We all watched the violence live on TV. We watched as insurrectionists stormed the Capitol, breaking down doors, tasing police officers and beating them bloody with flag poles. 

Now, President Trump is letting 1,500 of those who participated off the hook. (1/2)

President Trump said he would lower costs for Americans.

Tell me: How does revoking a decision to *lower* drug costs achieve that?

Thanks to this executive order, $2 generic drugs and cheaper access to new gene therapies are now on the chopping block.

https://t.co/E6P47a5jcc

Maine is now a leader in wind energy. The benefits have been significant.

Stopping offshore wind isn’t just incredibly shortsighted; it’s based on bad information. The risks of turbines are overblown—and pale in comparison to the impacts of fossil fuels.

https://t.co/rJ2ZIV0TeW

January 6th was one of the darkest days in our nation’s history. To pardon those involved is a shocking dismissal of our justice system, and an insult to the brave heroes who defended the Capitol and the Constitution that day.

President Trump also pardoned 1,500 people involved in the violent January 6th insurrection—including some from Maine. People who stormed the Capitol, assaulted police officers, and tried to disrupt the democratic process. https://t.co/9VZUan15XO

Oil prices often *increase* with production spikes!
 
There is no energy emergency. In fact, burning more fossil fuels only exacerbates the *actual* emergency: climate change.

This is all about lining the pockets of Big Oil billionaires. (2/2)

https://t.co/o5D6WAKVav

One of President Trump’s first Executive Orders was to declare a “national energy emergency.”

Here are the facts: The U.S. now produces more oil and gas than any country in history. The issue isn’t getting more gas and oil out of the ground; it's finding people to buy it! (1/2) https://t.co/yEctjmJmDS

As an American, she was the best of us—smart, creative, and wholeheartedly committed to making our country better.

Her legacy will inspire generations. And her work will be carried on.

Rest in power, Cecile. (3/3)

As president of Planned Parenthood, she fought tirelessly for healthcare access and equality, at a time when women’s rights were increasingly coming under attack. 

As cofounder of Supermajority, she helped women voters better understand their profound political power. (2/3)

I’m deeply saddened to hear of the passing of Cecile Richards—a feminist icon, a champion for reproductive rights, and someone who loved Maine, spending many summers on Casco Bay. (1/3)

https://t.co/cCKQ3cZLbc

These actions set the tone for what our country will face the next four years.

I will find common ground with this Administration where possible, but I will stand  against any actions that undermine our values, harm vulnerable communities or roll back critical progress. (3/3)

While I appreciate the significance of Inauguration Day, my focus today is on the slew of dangerous Executive Orders Trump plans to sign within the first hours of his presidency. Mass deportations, blanket tariffs, Jan. 6 pardons, climate action rollbacks—the list goes on. (2/3)

Today, there will be a peaceful transfer of power as President Trump takes the oath of office and solemnly swears to "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States.” The fate of our nation and our democracy depend on him upholding this oath. (1/3)

As we honor the life and legacy of Dr. King, let us all take a moment to reflect on how his words and actions have impacted us; to celebrate the progress he helped make possible; and to ask what *we* can do to build on that legacy—and bring us closer to true justice and equality.

During speeches at Bowdoin College in Brunswick and Saint Francis College in Biddeford (now UNE), King talked about the moral imperative of achieving equality. About putting an end to segregation once and for all. About the power of nonviolent action in combatting injustice.

In 1964, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. came to Maine—and shared a message of hope and resilience that still resonates today.
 
https://t.co/oOlNDq2rjZ

@NatlParkService @jkputnamphoto The 2025 free entrance days are:
 
Jan. 20 – Martin Luther King, Jr. Day
April 19 – First Day of National Park Week
June 19 – Juneteenth
Aug. 4 – Great American Outdoors Act Signing Day
Sept. 27 – National Public Lands Day
Nov. 11 – Veterans Day

Don't miss out on the 6 free admission days @NatlParkService has designated for 2025—including #MLKDay!

Whether you’ve always wanted to visit Acadia in the winter, or happen to be near another National Park, there's no better way to celebrate our country.

📸: @jkputnamphoto https://t.co/Vze5KH0Grw

I am ready to work with the Trump Administration to make #MakeAmericaHealthyAgain more than just a slogan.
📰Read my new op-ed in @thehill https://t.co/wqE2XRD1ER

That’s why we must take proactive steps to address the climate crisis, invest in forest management, and support fire-prevention measures. By learning from the past and taking action now, we can protect our communities, our forests, and our future. (2/2)

https://t.co/sF4Vimpvti

In 1947, wildfires burned more than 200,000 acres, destroyed 1,300 homes, and killed 16 people.
 
And it happened in Maine.

A disaster like what we're seeing in California is unlikely. But it’s not impossible. Especially as our climate gets hotter, drier, and windier. (1/2)
Let this moment serve as a beacon of hope and a testament to the enduring fight for equality. (5/5)

I thank the President for his leadership and for standing on the right side of history. I also urge the Archivist of the United States to promptly publish the ERA as the 28th Amendment, ensuring its full promise becomes a reality for everyone in America. (4/5)

It reinforces our nation’s commitment to addressing inequalities, closing the gender pay gap, defending reproductive rights, and combating gender-based violence. This is a monumental victory for the movement, and a reminder that progress is possible when we work together. (3/5)

Maine ratified the ERA in 1974, and in 2020, it reached the threshold of 38 states needed for full ratification. Today’s action by @POTUS reflects the tireless efforts of generations of advocates, organizers, and lawmakers who have fought to guarantee equal rights for all. (2/5)

More than a century after the #EqualRightsAmendment was first introduced, @POTUS has taken a historic step by affirming that the ERA should be the law of the land and officially recognized as the 28th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. (1/5)

https://t.co/Vn1U6sQgeq

I helped secure critical federal disaster relief funds for Maine to recover from last year's devastating storms.

If you work in one of these sectors and has experienced significant disaster losses, please fill out this survey:
https://t.co/IslKm4F8Ou

Today, we're reminded how close the PFAS crisis hits to home.

Maine inspectors found PFAS contamination on more than 100 farms and 500 residential properties.

I will do everything in my power to continue to raise this issue—and help impacted Mainers.

https://t.co/9k8w3AEeML

There is still a lot of uncertainty; the Israeli Cabinet needs to approve the deal, hostages need to be released, and humanitarian aid needs to pour into Gaza. I remain cautiously optimistic, but this is a promising step forward. (3/3)

This could not have been achieved without tireless diplomatic efforts to bring both parties to the table, and I am grateful the Biden Administration got this agreement across the finish line before leaving office. (2/3)

🧵I am relieved that after 467 days of fighting, over 47,000 Palestinian deaths, more than 2,000 Israeli deaths, and unfathomable destruction and devastation, Israel and Hamas have reached a long overdue agreement to cease hostilities and release hostages. (1/3)

I'm committed to defending those gains, fighting back against attempts to erode our ability to combat the climate crisis, while ensuring we fully fund our trust responsibilities to Tribal Nations, preserve our national parks and monuments, and protect our cultural agencies. (2/2)

As we navigate a Republican-controlled Congress and another Trump presidency, I’m grateful to my colleagues for entrusting me to lead the Interior Appropriations Subcommittee, which will no doubt be on the frontlines of Republican attacks on the climate progress we’ve made. (1/2) https://t.co/eO6dUyQxVS

35 years ago, the FDA banned the use of Red Dye No. 3 in cosmetics because of its potential cancer risk. My colleagues and I have long pushed to ban this dangerous dye from our nation's food supply, and finally, @US_FDA has acted. 

This is long overdue!

https://t.co/S82r13TfWE

DID YOU KNOW?: Radon is the leading cause of lung cancer among nonsmokers in the U.S. Here in Maine, more than 35% of radon test results exceed @EPA's “action level.”

January is National Radon Action Month, and the perfect time to get your home tested.
 
https://t.co/qw5eucY2Df

The Maine Ag Trades Show kicks off today! This event beautifully captures our state’s agriculture legacy.

I remain committed to passing a #FarmBill that ensures our farmers are able to create *their* legacies—and builds on Maine’s agricultural heritage.

https://t.co/hW8aBZGvaL

I founded the Slow Fashion Caucus to highlight fast fashion’s waste—and to celebrate reused clothing.

Maine’s Lost & Found pop-up market embodies this—cutting waste, sparking creativity, and supporting our local economy.

Slow fashion *is* fashion!

https://t.co/CwJXYmx2js

⚡️NEWS⚡️: Thanks to the #InflationReductionAct, Maine’s Fox Islands Electric Cooperative will receive $8.7M to expand renewable energy. 

Since 2008, the Fox Islands have led the way in rural clean energy. This is the next big step in that endeavor.

https://t.co/aokrIL340Z

Let’s face it: Filing taxes is never fun. But it *should* be easy.

Starting today, millions of Americans with an adjusted gross income of <$84K can file their taxes for FREE through the IRS. Some states are also offering free filing—including Maine.

https://t.co/D4zpKEv0H5

If there’s one thing that defines the American spirit, it’s innovation. Congress formally reauthorizing @US_EDA  should be celebrated. Not just for the bipartisan nature of the bill; but for the incredible economic potential it'll help unleash—including here in Maine.

Let’s honor him by continuing to fight for the future he envisioned—a future where we tackle the climate crisis head-on with the urgency it demands.

Rest in peace, Mr. President. Thank you for your unwavering belief in a better, more sustainable world. https://t.co/VLv14nV4LO

President Carter left an indelible mark on our country. From his work on global peace to the largest expansion of our National Parks, his legacy is one of service, compassion, and courage. https://t.co/V2iMrSUw3M

Those very panels, once a symbol of hope, still inspire future generations—right here in Maine, where they now reside at Unity College. And Maine is already leading the way in clean energy, showing what’s possible when we take bold action. https://t.co/YS9OEjUDLH

Where would we be today if we had sustained Carter’s vision+spent the last 45 yrs investing in renewables? We wouldn’t just be further along in combating the climate crisis, we would be leading the world in clean energy innovation +reaping the economic benefits of that leadership

But just a few years later, the Reagan administration tore those panels down, signaling a dangerous denial of the climate crisis (and a lack of understanding of the economic value of being ahead on the innovations of renewal energy) —a denial we are still fighting to overcome.

I’ll never forget casting my first-ever vote for him in 1976, or how inspired I felt seeing solar panels on the White House for the 1st time. It was a bold, forward-looking statement: America must embrace renewable energy to combat the climate crisis+achieve energy independence. https://t.co/aN2zw6ViLQ

Today, as our nation observes a National Day of Mourning for President Jimmy Carter, I’m reflecting on his lasting legacy—on our nation, our world, and our planet.

🧵 https://t.co/r7cEFNVUnL
Honored to be reelected as Vice Chair of the @SEEC—and so proud to continue working with my amazing colleagues to encourage stronger American leadership on climate issues.

What’s happening in California—lives lost, more than 1,000 buildings destroyed, massive fires fueled by 100mph winds—is tragic and terrifying. 

My thoughts are with all who've been affected, and the brave first responders putting their lives on the line.

https://t.co/n2E5prSzgc

We need immigration policies that target serious criminal activity, while preserving constitutional protections + community policing strategies that keep all residents safe.

Simply put, this bill is about politics, not protecting communities. That's why I voted against it. (5/5)

Undocumented people convicted of felonies are already subject to deportation. I support strong border security and prosecuting crimes, but this bill's broad scope would likely result in extended detentions for minor crimes, separating families and disrupting communities. (4/5)

The mandatory detention requirement would also strain local law enforcement, while failing to meaningfully improve public safety. Research shows immigration status alone is not predictive of criminal behavior. This bill risks eroding community trust in law enforcement. (3/5)

This bill requires mandatory detention for undocumented individuals arrested or charged with theft or burglary, even before a conviction. This contradicts our fundamental presumption of innocence and due process rights that protect all persons within U.S. jurisdiction. (2/5)

🧵I’ve received a lot of questions and comments about why I voted NO on the Laken Riley Act. 

Here’s why: (1/5)

Thanks to a grant from @USDOT, @CityPortland is now much closer to launching the redevelopment of Franklin St., which could bring enormous benefits to residents + visitors.

I’m pleased about this important step toward creating a safer, more equitable, and more livable Portland. https://t.co/FbLMsgCD0i

NEWS: Unpaid medical bills will no longer appear on credit reports.

We must do more to address the ridiculous costs of healthcare. But I commend the Biden Admin for taking this step.

No one should have to forgo their dream of owning a home because of insurance company greed.

We’re already seeing the long-term consequences of climate change here in Maine. By pursuing climate-smart policies, we can help slow the warming, protect our natural resources, and preserve what makes Maine such a special place to live, work, and play.

It’s wicked cold in Maine this week, as it should be in January. But don’t let that fool you. 

Maine’s lakes are freezing later and thawing earlier, cutting the ice season by more than two weeks. That’s bad news for our economy—and our ecosystems.

https://t.co/J5zn35JAxp

The risks of offshore drilling—to local communities and economies, to marine ecosystems, and to human health—far outweigh the potential benefits.

No president has protected more American lands+waters than President Biden. It’s a legacy that he—and all of us—should be proud of 👏
UPDATE: Following our letter, @POTUS is taking action to protect more than 625 million acres of American waters from future offshore oil and natural-gas drilling, including the entire East Coast!

Today, Congress will certify the election.
VP Harris will preside over the certification.
Pres. Biden will not incite a violent insurrection to disrupt the process.
There will be a peaceful transfer of power.
THIS is the American way. THIS is democracy.
Never take it for granted. https://t.co/zkx6ekWUV5

Just wrapped up a productive trip to the #PAFarmShow w/ @HouseAgGOP Chair @CongressmanGT +@houseagdems RM @RepAngieCraig

The #FarmBill is one of the most important bipartisan bills we pass. Proud to work across the aisle to support farmers & rural communities. Let’s get it done! https://t.co/E6Gc9d6uXf
No one says it better than Leader @RepJeffries. @HouseDemocrats are united and ready to get to work for the American people 🇺🇸 https://t.co/uUSfBWZBNd

The fact that many Republicans want to *repeal* the IRA—and the $2,000-a-month price cap—just goes to show how out of touch they are with the struggles of ordinary Americans. 

We can’t let that happen.

Thanks to the #InflationReductionAct, seniors were already saving on lower prescription-drug costs ($1 billion during the first six months of 2024 alone). Now, they’ll keep even more money in their pockets. https://t.co/450OmQoH9V

HUGE congratulations to Maine’s own Mary Bonauto on receiving the Presidential Citizens Medal from @POTUS! Her historic work in Obergefell v. Hodges affirmed the right to marry who you love and continues to inspire the fight for justice, equality, and dignity for all 👏🏻🏳️‍🌈 https://t.co/9tgZ7zhsPG

Trump's stance on worker visas is baffling: supporting H-2B visas used by seasonal industries like those in Maine and Florida, while pushing widespread restrictions on immigration? 

He has not even taken office yet, and already he is out of step with his biggest allies on policy https://t.co/7X4xJMqw7Y

@CleanEnergyBiz released its 2024 State of Clean Energy report. Maine ranked high in several categories: 

🟢 #3 in renewable generation
🟢 #5 in energy efficiency
🟢 #7 lowest CO2 emissions

Here's to Maine continuing to be a leader in clean energy!

https://t.co/MYvPgGCzK2 https://t.co/8IdeDalxkF

Happy #NewYear Maine!
As we welcome 2025, let’s reflect on the resilience, kindness,+community spirit that make our state so special. Here’s to a year of new opportunities+working together to build a brighter future for all Mainers. As ever, it's my honor to serve you in Congress https://t.co/4ZHpkAhIoa

I'm so proud of what we’ve accomplished together this year for Maine’s 1st District! From advocating for key legislation to securing $370 million for our communities, it’s been an honor to serve you. 

Here are some highlights before we ring in 2025! 🌲✨ #2024Wrapped https://t.co/JQFZTE2P3I

At 100, America’s longest living president maintained a commitment to election integrity, fighting poverty, and environmental protection until his last days. 

My thoughts are with the Carter family.

Even after leaving office, President Carter remained dedicated to the greater good – safeguarding free and fair elections around the world and with his bare hands building affordable housing alongside Habitat for Humanity for over 30 years.

Whether he was putting solar panels on the White House before many understood their full potential or giving up his humble peanut farm to prevent even a hint of impropriety as president, Jimmy Carter demonstrated how the nation’s top executive can lead by example. https://t.co/4pN6lPZitn
A joyous Kwanzaa to all who celebrate. May your days be filled with love, light, and community in abundance. ✨

In 2004, Maine artist Daniel Minter was commissioned to design a stamp for the U.S. Postal Service in honor of Kwanzaa. Looking at it now, the image he created feels more vibrant and powerful than ever. The colors. The pride. The sense of love and community. https://t.co/MDWOyzwUqx

This Hanukkah, let us honor the indelible impact Maine’s Jewish community has made on our state, by ensuring that the principles that exemplify this holiday—resilience, generosity, the power of community—continue to light our way forward. 

Happy Hanukkah to all who celebrate! https://t.co/Qc43tPCp8Y

For decades, people of all faiths and backgrounds have gathered in cities and towns throughout Maine for menorah-lighting ceremonies. Whenever I attend one of these events, I’m always amazed by the spirit of inclusivity and peace. By the sense of togetherness.
Merry Christmas to all who celebrate, from my family to yours, and with the heartfelt hope that this day finds you where—and with whom—you truly belong. https://t.co/F4mwSgP1cY

More than anything, though, Christmas is about being with the ones we love. It’s about giving of ourselves. It’s about hope. Joy. Community. Peace. And so many other beautiful things. The best things in life. And a nice bowl of fish chowder (my favorite) to go with it.
There’s nothing quite like Christmastime in Maine. Lobster trap trees. The smell of woodsmoke. Downtowns decked with tinsel and lights. The unrivaled beauty of snow on the landscape (usually).

Now, whenever I see a lighthouse all aglow, I’ll think of these traditions, and how the holiday spirit continues to be a beacon for our coastal communities—and everyone who calls Maine home.

Merry Christmas Eve to all.

(And thanks to Dennis Tangney, Jr. for the amazing photo.) https://t.co/W3ZNyyQn7A

Lighthouse keepers would often light an extra lantern to help guide sailors safely ashore on Christmas Eve. For those who lived on-site with their families, a feast of seafood was a common way to celebrate. Calm seas on Christmas Eve were seen as a good omen for the year ahead.
Stunning sunset tonight. How lucky are we to call Maine home? https://t.co/rzzxEsCB5b

This year, Portland’s East End Community School was chosen to decorate Maine’s tree on the Pathway.

I want to extend my warmest congratulations to the entire EECS community on this amazing honor. Your decorations look beautiful in front of the @WhiteHouse! 🎄 https://t.co/xOOipY5Mcd

In 1954, 31 years after the National Christmas Tree was first displayed, each state + territory was honored with its own, smaller tree. The “Pathway of Peace” has been a mainstay ever since—and a lovely reminder that, whatever our differences, we’re all part of something bigger.

I proudly cosponsored and helped pass this bill, and while we still have a great deal of work to do to strengthen Social Security for future generations, I’m proud to stand behind thousands of Mainers in the fight to receive the retirement benefits they deserve.

G’mar chatima tova to my Jewish friends—and all who celebrate. May you have an easy and meaningful fast, and may you forever find hope and renewal.

In Judaism, there’s a greeting that people often use on Yom Kippur: G'mar chatima tova. It means “May you be inscribed in the Book of Life for good.” It’s such a beautiful, hopeful sentiment. One I think all of us draw something from. Especially in times of sadness + uncertainty.

Today is often associated with forgiveness and atonement. But it’s also about renewal. About hope for a better future. It’s about recognizing that we—all of us—can be better. Do better. Live better. Love better.
On this #YomKippur, I know the hearts of many in the Jewish community are heavy with the unimaginable suffering happening in the world.

The devastation caused by Helene is tragic. More than 200 have died. Hundreds more are missing. Entire communities, gone. It’ll take years for the region to recover. But Americans are stepping up—as we always do. From government agencies + first responders to ordinary citizens.
Today, we look back in mourning on the brutal and tragic events of October 7—while calling on all parties to do what’s necessary to achieve a real, lasting peace.

For the hostages that remain in Gaza, for the humanitarian aid that’s so desperately needed, we *must* achieve a ceasefire, and take the first, meaningful steps towards deescalating this horrific conflict.
Tragically, the violence we saw on October 7 has only escalated. To date, 40,000 Gazans have lost their lives—most of them women and children. Now, a new war has erupted in Lebanon.
Let us remember the victims. Let us hold their loved ones in our hearts. And let us continue to urge the safe return of the remaining hostages.

1 yr ago, the people of Israel endured one of the most horrific terrorist attacks in their history. More than 1,400 people, including 300 children, were killed that day. In its awful scale+indiscriminate scope, Oct 7 was the deadliest day for the Jewish people since the Holocaust
